body.p: По доходящим сюда слухам, что на Москве хотят переводить новое издание Бомарше всех сочинений Вольтера в 69 томах состоящее, прикажите Управе Благочиния и обер-полицмейстеру наблюдать, чтоб таковое издание отнюдь не было печатаемо ни в одной типографии без цензуры и апробации преосвященнаго митрополита Московскаго.According to K.A. Papmehl, in this letter Catherine was setting a 'trap' for Platon, metropolitan of Moscow, who had been denounced by Petr Alekseev as using Catherine's correspondence with Voltaire as a way of discrediting her Orthodoxy (see Catherine's letter to Khrapovitsky of 17 September 1789 and the editorial note on it). Papmehl does not mention that there really was a large-scale effort to translate Voltaire, if not from the Beaumarchais edition, being undertaking in Moscow at that time: Catherine may really have heard about it. One might also think that, seeing the manifest absurdity of Alekseev's accusation, Catherine in the present letter reasserted her trust in Platon and her continued desire to use him in her service. One might imagine that she knew that Alekseev would interpret her letter as giving him free rein to attack Platon, and she thus indirectly reestablished the Metropolitan's authority. Rather than proving a two-faced and malicious enemy of Platon, she perhaps used the two letters in question to cleverly balance the two rival clergymen and to ensure that she could continue to use Platon as an unfanatical clergyman and censor, as well as Alekseev as a source of information. It is worth noting that while Catherine was not pleased about the publication of her letters by Beaumarchais and was already concerned about the French Revolution, she also at this time did not regard Voltaire as an enemy: her letters to Grimm show her reading Voltaire's Henriade and citing Voltaire as a royalist still a year later in 1790. It is rather amusing, though, that she remembered only 69 volumes of the Kehl edition: it was in fact 70 volumes. She must have wanted (consciously or unconsciously) to exclude the volume containing her correspondence from the full extent of Beaumarchais's edition.

Since rumours have reached us that in Moscow there are plans to translate Beaumarchais's new edition of all the works of Voltaire in 69 volumes, order the Police Board and the senior police constable to ensure that such an edition is by no means printed on any press without the censorship and approval of the Right Reverend Metropolitan of Moscow.
